structures.shortDescription: A subcortical part of the forebrain and a critical component of the basal ganglia. It consists of the caudate nucleus and putamen, and receives input from the cerebral cortex. The striatum plays a key role in motor planning, decision-making, motivation, and reward perception.
functions: Coordinating multiple aspects of cognition, including motor and action planning
Regulating movement execution and inhibiting unwanted movements
Processing reward-related information and reinforcement learning
Contributing to decision-making processes and habit formation
Working with other basal ganglia structures to maintain movement control

structures.shortDescription: Cavities within the brain that are filled with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). There are four ventricles: two lateral ventricles (one in each cerebral hemisphere), the third ventricle in the diencephalon, and the fourth ventricle in the hindbrain.
functions: Providing physical protection to the brain by acting as a fluid cushion
Contributing to waste clearance from the brain
Helping maintain homeostasis of the brain environment
Serving as landmarks for neuroanatomical orientation

structures.shortDescription: A large, egg-shaped structure of gray matter located in the diencephalon, near the center of the brain. It acts as a major relay station for sensory and motor information between the body and the cerebral cortex, and plays a role in consciousness, sleep, and alertness.
functions: Relaying sensory information (except smell) to the cerebral cortex
Relaying motor information from the cerebellum and basal ganglia to the cerebral cortex
Playing a role in regulating consciousness, sleep, and wakefulness
Involvement in learning and memory, particularly episodic memory
Processing and modulating information received from other thalamic nuclei

structures.shortDescription: A complex C-shaped structure embedded deep in the temporal lobe, playing a major role in learning and memory. It is crucial for the formation of new declarative memories (facts and events) and for spatial navigation.
functions: Consolidation of new memories (converting short-term to long-term memory)
Emotional behavior and regulation (working with amygdala)

structures.shortDescription: An almond-shaped set of neurons located deep in the brain's medial temporal lobe. It is a key component of the limbic system and is primarily involved in processing emotions such as fear, anxiety, and pleasure, as well as emotional memory.
functions: Processing emotions, especially fear and anxiety
Formation and storage of memories associated with emotional events (emotional memory)
Role in fear conditioning and learning

structures.shortDescription: The most superior part of the brainstem, connecting the forebrain (cerebrum and diencephalon) to the hindbrain (pons and medulla). It is involved in motor control, eye movement, and processing auditory and visual information.
functions: Controlling eye movements and visual reflexes
Processing auditory information and auditory reflexes
Regulation of consciousness and sleep-wake cycles (via reticular formation)

structures.shortDescription: A part of the brainstem situated above the medulla oblongata and below the midbrain. It serves as a major relay station for signals between the cerebrum and the cerebellum and is involved in functions like sleep, respiration, swallowing, bladder control, hearing, equilibrium, taste, eye movement, facial expressions, and posture.
functions: Relaying signals between the forebrain and the cerebellum
Influencing sleep-wake cycles and REM sleep
Playing a role in regulating breathing
Involved in control of facial movements and sensations
Processing sensory information related to hearing and balance

structures.shortDescription: The lowest part of the brainstem, connecting the brain to the spinal cord. It controls vital autonomic functions such as heartbeat, breathing, and blood pressure, as well as reflexes like vomiting, coughing, sneezing, and swallowing.
functions: Regulating vital autonomic functions (heartbeat, respiration, blood pressure)
Controlling reflexes such as coughing, sneezing, swallowing, and vomiting
Relaying nerve signals between the brain and spinal cord
Housing cranial nerve nuclei (IX, X, XI, XII)
Site of decussation (crossing over) of major motor pathways

structures.shortDescription: A large bundle of nerve fibers (white matter) connecting the left and right cerebral hemispheres, facilitating communication between them. It is crucial for integrating sensory, motor, and cognitive information processed by the two hemispheres.
functions: Connecting the left and right cerebral hemispheres
Integrating sensory, motor, and cognitive information from both hemispheres
Playing a role in coordinating movement and higher cognitive functions
Transfer of visual, auditory, and somatosensory information between hemispheres

structures.shortDescription: The stem-like part of the brain connecting the cerebral hemispheres with the spinal cord. It consists of the midbrain, pons, and medulla oblongata and controls autonomic functions essential for survival.
functions: Regulating vital autonomic functions (heartbeat, breathing, blood pressure)
Conveying sensory and motor signals between brain and body

structures.shortDescription: Located at the back of the brain beneath the occipital and temporal lobes, the cerebellum is a distinct structure with a heavily folded surface. It contains more neurons than the rest of the brain combined and plays a key role in motor control and coordination.
functions: Coordinating voluntary movements and fine motor skills
Contribution to certain cognitive functions like attention and language

structures.shortDescription: The largest lobe of the brain, located at the front of each cerebral hemisphere and responsible for executive functions such as decision-making, problem-solving, planning, and self-control. It houses the primary motor cortex that controls voluntary movements.
functions: Impulse control and inhibition of inappropriate behaviors

structures.shortDescription: Located on the sides of the brain, beneath the lateral fissure, the temporal lobes are involved in processing auditory information, understanding language, and forming and retrieving memories. They also play a role in emotion and visual perception.

Located behind the frontal lobe and above the temporal lobe, the parietal lobe processes sensory information from various parts of the body. It is involved in spatial navigation, attention, and integrating different sensory inputs.
functions: Processing sensory information from the skin (touch, temperature, pain)
Manipulation of objects and hand-eye coordination

structures.shortDescription: The smallest lobe of the brain, located at the back of each cerebral hemisphere. It is primarily responsible for visual processing, including color recognition, motion perception, and depth perception.
functions: Processing visual information from the eyes

structures.shortDescription: A small region of the cerebral cortex located deep within the lateral sulcus, beneath the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes. The insula is involved in consciousness, emotion, regulation, perception, motor control, and cognitive function.
functions: Interoceptive awareness (awareness of internal bodily signals)

structures.shortDescription: A region of the cerebral cortex that forms a collar around the corpus callosum and is part of the limbic system. It plays important roles in emotion formation and processing, learning, and memory.

A C-shaped structure in the basal ganglia that is part of the striatum. It plays important roles in learning, memory, reward, motivation, emotion, and romantic interaction, and is involved in movement control.
functions: Learning and memory, particularly procedural learning

structures.shortDescription: A round structure located at the base of the forebrain, forming part of the basal ganglia along with the caudate nucleus. It is involved in regulating movements and learning processes.
functions: Processing of motor and sensory information

structures.shortDescription: A major component of the basal ganglia consisting of two parts: internal (GPi) and external (GPe). It acts as the main output nucleus of the basal ganglia and plays a crucial role in motor control.
functions: Output control for the basal ganglia motor circuit

structures.shortDescription: A basal ganglia structure located in the midbrain that plays an important role in reward and movement. Degeneration of this area is associated with Parkinson's disease.

A small lens-shaped nucleus in the diencephalon that is part of the basal ganglia motor circuit. It plays a critical role in motor control and is a target for deep brain stimulation in Parkinson's disease.
functions: Fine motor control and movement precision
Integration of cortical and limbic inputs

structures.shortDescription: A small endocrine gland located near the center of the brain, between the two hemispheres. It produces melatonin and plays a crucial role in regulating circadian rhythms and sleep-wake cycles.
functions: Regulating circadian rhythms and sleep-wake cycles

structures.shortDescription: Often called the 'master gland,' this pea-sized endocrine gland is located at the base of the brain. It controls the function of most other endocrine glands and is divided into anterior and posterior lobes.
functions: Hormone production and regulation (growth hormone, ACTH, TSH)

structures.shortDescription: A small region at the base of the brain that links the nervous system to the endocrine system via the pituitary gland. It controls many automatic functions and maintains homeostasis.
